questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot with axes scaled by 10 pixels per unit. The y-axis ticks are at 5 (y=200), 10 (y=150), 15 (y=100). The line of best fit starts exactly at the y-intercept of 15 (pixel coordinates 50, 100) and slopes downward to intersect the x-axis at 15 (pixel coordinates 200, 250).
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. A line of best fit is also shown. Which of the following equations best represents the line of best fit?
questions.explanation: The line of best fit falls from left to right, indicating a negative slope. Visually, the line starts on the y-axis at the tick mark labeled <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn></math> and crosses the x-axis at the tick mark <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn></math>. The slope is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Thus, the equation is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the slope direction (positive vs. negative) and the y-intercept from the graph to select the correct line equation.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot of Distance vs Time. The x-axis is marked 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 hours. The y-axis is marked 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 miles. The data shows a negative trend. A blue line of best fit slopes downwards, passing through the y-axis at 70 and passing exactly through the intersection of grid lines for x=4 and y=30.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the remaining distance to a destination over time during a trip. What does the line of best fit predict for the remaining distance after <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn></math> hours?
questions.explanation: To find the predicted value, locate <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> on the horizontal axis (Time). Move vertically up to the line of best fit, and then move horizontally to the left to read the corresponding value on the vertical axis (Distance). The line passes through the point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, so the predicted distance is 30 miles.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot with a downward-opening parabolic curve. The x-axis is labeled 0, 5, 10. The y-axis is labeled 0, 25, 50. The vertex of the curve is clearly at (5, 50). The curve intersects the y-axis at 25.
questions.question: Of the following, which is the best model for the data in the scatterplot?
questions.explanation: The data forms a downward-opening parabola, which indicates a negative coefficient for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> (eliminating options A and B). The vertex of the parabola appears to be at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Checking option C, the vertex x-coordinate is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, and the y-coordinate is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. This matches the graph. Option D would have a vertex at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, which is incorrect.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the direction the parabola opens (up or down) and identify the vertex coordinates to select the correct quadratic equation.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot of candle height versus time. The y-axis (Height) has ticks at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20. The x-axis (Time) has ticks at 0, 10, 20, 30, 40. The data points show a linear decrease. A point is clearly visible at (10, 18) and another at (30, 12).
questions.question: The graph shows the height of a candle as it burns over time. What is the average rate of change in height, in centimeters per minute, from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn></math> minutes to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn></math> minutes? Enter your answer as a decimal.
questions.explanation: To find the average rate of change, identifying the height values at the specified times from the graph: At <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> min, the height is approximately <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>18</mn></math> cm. At <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math> min, the height is approximately <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>12</mn></math> cm. Calculate the rate of change: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>18</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>30</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>0.3</mn></math> cm/min.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing a negative linear trend. The y-axis has ticks at 0, 6, and 12. The x-axis has ticks at 0, 5, and 10. A blue line of best fit starts at the y-intercept (0, 12) and ends at the x-intercept (10, 0).
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. Which of the following is closest to the slope of the line of best fit?
questions.explanation: To estimate the slope, pick two distinct points on the line of best fit. The line starts at the y-intercept <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and crosses the x-axis at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. The slope formula is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math>. Substituting the points: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1.2</mn></math>.

At x=3, there is a distinct data point at y=16 (above the grid line for 15). The blue line of best fit passes below this point, crossing the vertical grid line x=3 at approximately y=13.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. A line of best fit for the data is also shown. Which of the following is closest to the difference between the y-coordinate of the data point with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and the y-value predicted by the line of best fit at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: To find the difference (residual), look at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The actual data point is located at approximately <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. The line of best fit at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> passes through approximately <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>. The difference is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>16</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot of velocity vs time. The y-axis has ticks for 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24. The x-axis has ticks for 0, 2, 4, 6, 8. The points show a negative linear trend. A specific point lies at (2, 20) and another at (6, 12).
questions.question: The graph shows the velocity <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>v</mi></math>, in meters per second, of an object <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> seconds after it started moving, for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the average rate of change, in meters per second per second, in the velocity from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Identify the velocity at the given times from the graph: At <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, the velocity <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. At <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, the velocity <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. The average rate of change is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.

questions.score_improvement_tip: Average rate of change is the slope between two points on the graph.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot of Sales versus Years since 2000. The x-axis ranges from 0 to 20 years. The y-axis ranges from 0 to 160 thousand. The data shows a negative trend. A blue line of best fit starts at the y-intercept (0, 160) and ends at the x-intercept (20, 0).
questions.question: The scatterplot above shows company sales every 5 years from 2000 to 2020. A line of best fit is shown, and its equation is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>160</mn></math>. What does the line of best fit predict about the decrease in sales over the 20-year period?

options.A: Each year, the average decrease was 8 thousand.
options.B: Each year, the average decrease was 160 thousand.
options.C: Every 5 years, the average decrease was 8 thousand.
options.D: Every 5 years, the average decrease was 160 thousand.

questions.explanation: The equation of the line is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> is the slope. Here, the slope is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. In the context of the graph where the x-axis represents years, the slope represents the rate of change per year. Therefore, a slope of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math> means sales decrease by an average of 8 thousand each year.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Interpret the slope of a linear model as the average rate of change per single unit of the x-variable.

questions.question: In an experiment, a sample is heated, and the temperature is recorded every minute. The graph above shows the temperature in degrees Celsius. During which <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math>-minute interval does the temperature increase at the greatest average rate?
questions.explanation: The average rate of change corresponds to the slope of the line segment connecting the points for a given interval. Visually, the segment from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> is the steepest, indicating the greatest vertical increase in temperature over that 1-minute period.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Compare the steepness (slope) of the segments between consecutive points to find the greatest rate of change.

questions.question: What is the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-value predicted by the line of best fit when <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: To find the predicted value, locate <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> on the horizontal axis. Follow the vertical line up to where it meets the line of best fit. Then, look horizontally to the left to find the corresponding <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-value. The line passes through the point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot for Data Set A showing a strong positive linear relationship. The x-axis and y-axis both range from 0 to 20 with tick marks every 5 units. The line of best fit passes exactly through (0,0), (10,10), and (20,20), indicating a slope of 1 and y-intercept of 0.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>, for data set A. A line of best fit is shown. Data set B is created by adding <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math> to the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate of each data point from data set A. Which of the following could be an equation of a line of best fit for data set B?
questions.explanation: The line of best fit for Data Set A passes through <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, so its slope is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math> and y-intercept is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn></math> (equation: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>). Adding <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math> to each <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate shifts the entire line vertically upwards by 5 units. The slope remains <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math>, but the new y-intercept becomes <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math>. Thus, the new equation is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.

questions.score_improvement_tip: Transformations on data points affect the intercept or slope accordingly. A vertical shift changes the y-intercept but keeps the slope constant.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing a quadratic relationship. The points rise from the left, reach a peak near x=5 (y=25), and then decrease, forming a parabolic shape that opens downward (like a mountain).
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. An equation for the model shown can be written as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math> are constants. Which of the following is true about <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The graph shows a parabola that opens downward (it has a maximum point). In the quadratic equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>, the coefficient <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math> determines the direction of the opening. When <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the parabola opens upward. When <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the parabola opens downward. Since this graph opens downward, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the concavity of the parabola: 'opening down' (frowning) means 'a' is negative; 'opening up' (smiling) means 'a' is positive.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot of data with exponential decay.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, x and y. An equation for the exponential model shown can be written as <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>x</mi></msup></math>, where a and b are positive constants. What is the value of b, rounded to the nearest hundredth?
questions.explanation: From the points, calculating the ratio of y-values for consecutive x-values (e.g., <math><mfrac><mn>150</mn><mn>200</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.75</mn></math>) gives <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.75</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For exponential models, find b using ratios of y-values.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing a positive linear relationship with a y-intercept of 50.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows data set C with a line of best fit. Data set D is created by multiplying each x-coordinate by 2. Which equation could be the line of best fit for D?
questions.explanation: The line of best fit in the scatterplot has a y-intercept of 50 and passes through points suggesting a slope of 1 (e.g., rising 1 unit for every 1 unit of x). The equation for the original data is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. When the x-coordinates are multiplied by 2 to create data set D, the new variable <math><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>new</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>new</mi></msub></math>. Substituting this into the original equation gives <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>new</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When x-values are multiplied by a factor k, the slope of the linear model is divided by k.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot with a negative linear correlation and a line of best fit y = -x + 30.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between x and y. If the line of best fit is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn></math>, what is the residual for the point where x=10?
questions.explanation: The residual is the difference between the actual y-value and the predicted y-value (<math><mtext>residual</mtext><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>actual</mtext></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>predicted</mtext></msub></math>). First, find the predicted value at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> using the equation: <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Next, identify the actual y-value from the scatterplot at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, which is 18. Finally, calculate the residual: <math><mn>18</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Residuals measure the vertical distance between a data point and the line of best fit.

questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing a positive linear relationship consistent with the equation y = x - 50.
questions.question: The line of best fit for the data is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. If a new data set is created by subtracting 10 from each y-value, what is the new slope?
questions.explanation: The slope of a linear equation <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> represents the rate of change. Subtracting a constant value (10) from each y-value shifts the entire line vertically downwards by 10 units. This transformation affects the y-intercept (which becomes <math><mi>b</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></math>) but does not change the steepness or slope of the line. Therefore, the new slope remains 1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Vertical shifts (adding/subtracting from y) change the y-intercept but leave the slope unchanged.

questions.question: Which transformation would linearize the data?
questions.explanation: Quadratic relationship suggests plotting against <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> for linearity.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Choose transformations based on the curve shape to achieve linearity.

questions.question: A data set has a line of best fit y = 2x + 3. If each x-value is increased by 4 and each y-value decreased by 6, what is the new line of best fit?
questions.explanation: New <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, <math><msup><mi>y</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Substitute: <math><msup><mi>y</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>  <math><msup><mi>y</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>11</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Adjust for shifts in both variables when transforming data.

questions.question: For the exponential model <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>x</mi></msup></math>, what is the predicted y when x=5?
questions.explanation: <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mo></mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>5</mn></msup><mo></mo><mn>32.768</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Calculate exponential values step by step for accuracy.

questions.question: If the data is fit with <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, and then a new set multiplies y by -1, what is the new slope?
questions.explanation: Multiplying <math><mi>y</mi></math> by -1 leads to <math><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, which simplifies to <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></math>. Thus, the slope becomes <math><mo>-</mo><mi>m</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Scaling y scales the slope by the same factor.
